B1DF1D26488841BDA535FC41A217AEA4.description: SSEC.G.37.b: explore job and career options and explain the significance of investment in education, training, and skill development (human capital) as it relates to future earnings by using primary and secondary sources

E482A8D4422845FABFA66D9F1FE62462.description: SSEC.G.37.a: identify skills that are required to be successful in the workplace including positive work ethics, punctuality, time management, team work, communication skills, and good character by identifying and writing about issues or problems and alternative solutions

46EC3B3616AD45A2BAE6B13CDFA0A581.description: SSEC.G.37: describe how the earnings of workers are determined in the marketplace

626166DB38FF4518BC9BABFDDC94460B.description: SSEC.G.36.b: explain the costs and benefits associated with different types of insurance including deductibles, premiums, shared liability, and asset protection by using graphs, diagrams, graphs, and/or diagrams

544883ED17FD4F23B933FAA2AFE20AA6.description: SSEC.G.36.a: list and describe various types of insurance such as automobile, health, life, disability, renter's, and property by using graphs, diagrams, graphs, and/or diagrams

F88D3B48A4784585BD4D6623F3FDB665.description: SSEC.G.36: describe how insurance and other risk-management strategies protect against financial loss

52F2CC4B301A432E9EB7EA4718C534D8.description: SSEC.G.35.c: define annual percentage rate (APR) and explain the difference between simple and compound interest rates, as well as fixed and variable interest rates by analyzing graphs, diagrams, and/or graphs

2415B2D50A8945DE8CCA6CA29E26A9F7.description: SSEC.G.35.b: compare interest rates on loans and credit cards from different institutions by analyzing graphs, diagrams, and/or graphs

5707FB4157E24C07BC622F82BD89E072.description: SSEC.G.35.a: describe factors that affect credit worthiness and the ability to receive favorable interest rates including character (credit score), collateral, and capacity to pay by analyzing information in order to formulate arguments that draw conclusions and make generalizations

03B08F039613491E81C87602FFF8D60F.description: SSEC.G.35: evaluate the costs and benefits of using credit

3DD81C5C35A4491C86884E1A7BCE26B0.description: SSEC.G.34.c: explain the impact of property taxes (proportional tax) on individuals and communities using primary and secondary sources including analyzing graphs and/or diagrams

9BB73DBAC22A48A4A63444BABC6071DC.description: SSEC.G.34.b: explain how an increase in sales tax (regressive tax) affects different income groups

0C4F2950AA55453ABB0FC2FE1980AC5F.description: SSEC.G.34.a: define and provide examples for progressive, regressive, and proportional taxes

F7B2BA0A352D4654954369F0E1C91744.description: SSEC.G.34: explain how changes in taxation can have an impact on an individual's spending and saving choices

D53DE7DBDB79473CBDB3E5B9C3593CAB.description: SSEC.G.33.d: evaluate the risk and return of a variety of savings and investment options, including: savings accounts, certificates of deposit, retirement accounts, stocks, bonds, and mutual funds by writing arguments, informative text, and/or explanatory text that draw conclusions and make generalizations

3B34CDD27C6A4879863BD37A8DD7BAFF.description: SSEC.G.33.c: give examples of the direct relationship between risk and return

D1CEF2263FB644B4AE1A92C729447062.description: SSEC.G.33.b: explain reasons for the spread between interest charged and interest earned

A3A080B645274C6E8F8509F4FFBDD97B.description: SSEC.G.33.a: compare services offered by different financial institutions, including banks, credit unions, payday lenders, and title pawn lenders using primary and secondary sources

02751491F37B478883FC45D1A1AFF954.description: SSEC.G.33: explain that banks and other financial institutions are businesses that channel funds from savers to investors

C7753FA9EE4F481184596BDDFF51B276.description: SSEC.G.32.b: create a budget that includes a savings or financial investment plan for a future goal

0EB186EDAE8B4942A59095349A87E912.description: SSEC.G.32.a: use a rational decision making model to evaluate the costs and benefits of post-high school life choices (i.e., college, technical school, military enlistment, workforce participation, or another options)

8E500BD05BB44481B4AF259CEAB531A7.description: SSEC.G.32: apply rational decision-making to personal spending and saving choices

25C30B9A515D471DA942A914FABDAC72.description: SSEC.F.31.c: explain why some groups benefit and others lose when exchange rates change by analyzing charts and/or graphs

883006BC939C4FA59950C7BAAA76322F.description: SSEC.F.31.b: interpret changes in exchange rates in regard to appreciation and depreciation of currency by analyzing charts and/or graphs

1EB42BBFC9154215A0050E968E3824A6.description: SSEC.F.31.a: define exchange rate as the price of one nation's currency in terms of another nation's currency

47276FF42D434C22B2B09B4B405FFD5A.description: SSEC.F.31: explain how changes in exchange rates can have an impact on the purchasing power of groups in the United States and in other countries

C7BB4ED118024DDE81E40A48BCCBF1CF.description: SSEC.F.30.d: evaluate arguments for and against free trade (protectionism) by identifying and writing about issues, outcomes, and/or problems

31E6272DADB24BF9A28FF71AA206837E.description: SSEC.F.30.c: describe the purpose of trading blocs such as the EU, United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), and ASEAN by analyzing maps, charts and/or tables

7568D107B3EF44F888D22DA9F881EF09.description: SSEC.F.30.b: identify costs and benefits of trade barriers to consumers and producers over time

9BF42CB0A5CF41A3BAD034F206B53CEC.description: SSEC.F.30.a: define trade barriers such as tariffs, quotas, embargoes, standards, and subsidies

F07810D6B1DA4DE9A70465AE32299C0F.description: SSEC.F.30: explain why countries sometimes erect trade barriers and sometimes advocate free trade

4CEF60790B914DB685D4BBCE6ABEAE3A.description: SSEC.F.29.b: explain that most international trade takes place because of comparative advantage in the production of a good or service as a result of opportunity cost by analyzing charts and/or tables

2542232DFA784B218413CBBBCB5B2A1E.description: SSEC.F.29.a: define and distinguish between absolute advantage and comparative advantage by comparing their similarities and differences

BFB8BAA150664B74853898102E026106.description: SSEC.E.28.b: introduce different types of taxes, including proportional, progressive, and regressive. Explain the effect on the economy of the government's taxing and spending decisions in promoting price stability, full employment, and economic growth by analyzing graphs, tables, graphs, and/or diagrams

2B24D77987184CAFB3FE6FCC18BB8D91.description: SSEC.E.28: explain how the U.S. government uses fiscal policy to promote price stability, full employment, and economic growth

0A547AA2CF9B423F8D4BD80E58D0FFE2.description: SSEC.E.27.e: describe the organization of the Federal Reserve System (12 Districts, Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), and Board of Governors) by analyzing graphs and/or diagrams

7A5FD83368974FDD9E0D944011275A33.description: SSEC.E.27.d: define the tools of monetary policy including reserve requirement, discount rate, open market operations, and interest on reserves

59B8C6AB2B154D7BBCFB61BE3CCC83B7.description: SSEC.E.27.b: describe the organization of the Federal Reserve System (12 Districts, Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), and Board of Governors) by analyzing graphs and/or diagrams

142E9534A7B442BB85A2E7ED4AA6A7E4.description: SSEC.E.27.a: explain the roles/functions of money as a medium of exchange, store of value, and unit of account/standard of value

8E04A024B2FB472FB3D9A86976ECC2D5.description: SSEC.E.27: explain the role and functions of the Federal Reserve System

B519FB29CEE04901BCFDC7BD64091531.description: SSEC.E.26.g: define the stages of the business cycle including: peak, contraction, trough, recovery/expansion, as well as specify the difference between a recession and a depression by analyzing graphs and/or diagrams

765F0A38F5664FB494B0FB6A00D8DE65.description: SSEC.E.26.f: identify seasonal, structural, cyclical, and frictional unemployment

5BF8284B9C36434FA7053B37AB1678BB.description: SSEC.E.26.e: give examples of who benefits and who loses from unanticipated inflation

C44B5D34B28E4D20838F4F4A0FFBFEE1.description: SSEC.E.26.d: define unemployment rate, Consumer Price Index (CPI), inflation, real GDP, aggregate supply, and aggregate demand and explain how each is used to evaluate the macroeconomic goals from AKS 26b; compare and contrast aggregate demand and demand, and aggregate supply and supply

860265C015E64F55AFBEE28A640379A5.description: SSEC.E.26.c: define Gross Domestic Product (GDP) as the sum of Consumer Spending, Investment, Government Spending, and Net Exports (output expenditure model) Be able to identify what is included and excluded from GDP

3A32E446BCD94F6394989F1034CA5321.description: SSEC.E.26.b: identify and describe the macroeconomic goals of steady economic growth, stable prices, and full employment based on the broad social goals of the four economic systems by constructing a charts, tables, graphs, and/or diagrams

B7134E985B834C648A9D874306AFEC00.description: SSEC.E.26.a: incorporate the role of government into the circular flow model and check that information remains consistent when analyzing a graph and/or diagram

D8CD324E2CA34648AA96D4095BE2CE20.description: SSEC.E.26: illustrate the means by which economic activity is measured

D15E46DEE9F54CC9A6D86964EAC8DF1F.description: SSEC.D.25.c: explain the differences between the following types of monopolies - technological monopoly, natural monopoly, geographical monopoly, and government monopoly by constructing and/or analyzing charts and/or tables

67642AB02DBC406DAA0E774F01CD57C9.description: SSEC.D.25.b: identify the basic characteristics of the market structures of monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition, and pure (perfect) competition with regard to number of sellers, barriers to entry, price control (price makers vs. price takers), and product differentiation by constructing a chart, table, or diagram

AFB49F7F0B404AB584E6D16A25E1CEA3.description: SSEC.D.25.a: compare and contrast three forms of business organization—sole proprietorship, partnership, and corporation with regard to number of owners, liability, lifespan, decision-making, ease to start and close, and taxation by constructing charts and/or tables

C79B2B2A368D4BF58C027D625337B62B.description: SSEC.D.25: explain the organization and role of business and analyze the four types of market structures in the U.S. economy

79962909008C4DD0A2E500E7488E9603.description: SSEC.D.24.h: explain and illustrate on a graph how prices set too high (e.g., price floors) create surpluses, and prices set too low (e.g., price ceilings) create shortages

CF5AB2731C5F468B8E170BD72DA9A074.description: SSEC.D.24.g: explain the difference between elastic and inelastic demand and its responsiveness to change in price by analyzing charts and graphs

917D3F9F9DEB4E6AB90516BA668B2C31.description: SSEC.D.24.f: identify the determinants (shifters) of demand (e.g., changes in related goods (substitutes/complements), income, consumer expectations, consumer preferences/tastes, and number of consumers) and illustrate the effects on a supply and demand graph

A4222FD4C6E24FD9B4DACF4D115A2570.description: SSEC.D.24.e: identify the determinants (shifters) of supply (e.g., changes in costs of productive resources/inputs, government regulations, number of sellers/producers, producer expectations, technology, and education) and illustrate the effects on a supply and demand graph

5551FF9CC7584697A543E46060AA8212.description: SSEC.D.24.d: illustrate on a graph how supply and demand determine equilibrium price and quantity

8138F55A09874CB8B55D70213E9208E2.description: SSEC.D.24.c: describe the role of buyers and sellers in determining market clearing price (i.e., equilibrium) by analyzing charts and graphs

249857F8D4CF4EA3B793547C4F285412.description: SSEC.D.24.b: distinguish between supply and quantity supplied, and demand and quantity demanded by analyzing charts and graphs

3051313DB5884EF2A9FAF86A8D3DF146.description: SSEC.D.24.a: define the law of supply and the law of demand

D850916DE3CF4F8F87A1D3DD7C7AEC04.description: SSEC.D.24: explain how the Law of Demand, the Law of Supply, and prices work to determine production and distribution in a market economy

4E7FDC79738D4A7AAC7E44F4D0CBFB1B.description:
SSEC.D.23.b: explain the real flow of goods, services, resources, and money between and among
households and firms

9D0EF7980BBB4595AB28C04C036054AD.description:
SSEC.D.23.a: illustrate a circular flow diagram that includes the product market, the resource (factor)
market, households, and firms

543B0B8C35DF46E4B5D86544266BB8A8.description: SSEC.D.23: describe how households and businesses are interdependent and interact through the flow of goods, services, resources, and money

E62C9050FF934CBBB56DCEC2E3BEE03E.description: SSEC.C.22.d: analyze by means of a production possibilities curve: trade-offs, opportunity cost, growth, and efficiency

B4F9B5B67FCF4A2083983B0ED2318A14.description: SSEC.C.22.c: explain how investments in human capital (e.g., education, job training, and healthcare) can lead to a higher standard of living using primary and secondary sources (including charts and graphs)

159F0FCD88624833AA7E701112415B1A.description: SSEC.C.22.b: explain how investment in equipment and technology can lead to economic growth using primary and secondary resources to write arguments/explanatory text to draw conclusions

8DA3248701C348B1944DF0F1759003A3.description: SSEC.C.22.a: define productivity as the relationship of inputs to outputs

5EE3B48F37D848398B6EB2FE4E671AC5.description: SSEC.C.22: explain how productivity, economic growth, and future standards of living are influenced by investment in the four factors of production, including factories, machinery, new technology, and the health, education, and training of people

31EB5D2BEE554805B340AEAF1297BF8D.description: SSEC.C.21.b: explain the effects on consumers and producers caused by government regulation and deregulation  including interpreting political cartoons and writing explanatory text that draws conclusions

E05E8289D9F344C5A78ADEF9F03BDB37.description: SSEC.C.21.a: explain why government provides public goods and services, redistributes income, protects property rights, and resolves market failures using primary and secondary sources

6B94D13ACC9C4A60A12D4A2C08F5E984.description: SSEC.C.21: describe the roles of government in the United States economy (e.g., mixed or modified private/free enterprise economy)

BAC6EDCC274B4EFFAB46429154E4BBFA.description: SSEC.C.20.c: compare and contrast strategies used in different economic systems for allocating scarce resources, such as by price, majority rule, contests, force, sharing, lottery, authority, first-come-first-served, and personal characteristics

A8B0425201A6471395EDFC87136DE00F.description: SSEC.C.20.b: analyze how each type of system answers the three economic questions and meets the broad social and economic goals of freedom, security, equity, growth, efficiency, price stability, full employment, and sustainability, by constructing charts and tables

26DB3187CBEA4E34AD66094247E35268.description: SSEC.C.20.a: compare the similarities and differences of traditional, command, market, and mixed economic systems with regard to private ownership, profit motive, consumer sovereignty, competition, and government regulation

C0034029098343B0BE4C5BCFFC707F07.description: SSEC.C.20: compare and contrast different economic systems and explain how they answer the three basic economic questions: what to produce, how to produce, and for whom to produce

F55B270FCB97418A9294BEA95A5FF619.description: SSEC.C.19.b: explain that overall both parties gain as a result of voluntary, non-fraudulent exchange in the long term

D7DB8C04ADC04C9BB29D2648F9F1C699.description: SSEC.C.19.a: explain how and why individuals and businesses specialize, including division of labor using primary and secondary sources (including charts, tables, and graphs)

E1F3CD5FD723403A8DD84B0DC0123DFF.description: SSEC.C.19: explain how specialization and voluntary exchange positively influence buyers and sellers

8061EF1CB8F54F808D04A28179219C62.description: SSEC.C.18.c: explain that people, businesses, and governments respond to positive and negative incentives in predictable ways

B5354D7A603F468EBD6E43E099F296B1.description: SSEC.C.18.b: explain that rational decisions occur when the marginal benefits of an action equal or exceed the marginal costs by analyzing charts and/or tables that exemplify using cost-benefit analysis and a decision making model

1E3A71902D7C46089167D45A0F4419A4.description: SSEC.C.18.a: define marginal cost and marginal benefit in comparison to total cost and total benefit by analyzing charts and/or tables

B55C4D2932274122B26F5C4069BA92BE.description: SSEC.C.18: give examples of how rational decision-making entails comparing the marginal benefits and the marginal costs of an action

9AF21412F79347F8B0B21F67817A0C85.description: SSEC.C.17.e: explain opportunity cost and tradeoffs between two options through the use of a production possibilities curve/frontier by analyzing graphs and diagrams

58DCD778A1E84F6A935FD4B525892ADB.description: SSEC.C.17.d: define opportunity cost as the next best alternative given up when individuals, businesses, and governments confront scarcity by making choices

71D389CBDD174D5BB16188A72775B746.description: SSEC.C.17.c: explain the motivations that influence entrepreneurs to take risks (e.g., profit, job creation, innovation, and improving society) by formulating appropriate research questions

356EFA1BF01C4117A7D3E98E08AB3F82.description: SSEC.C.17.b: define and give examples of productive resources (i.e., factors of production): natural resources (i.e., land), human resources (i.e., labor and human capital), physical capital (i.e., capital goods and financial capital vs. money), and entrepreneurship by constructing charts and/or tables

4B0BB392D70942DDBF1969FD9CE3041B.description: SSEC.C.17.a: define scarcity as a basic condition that exists when unlimited wants exceed limited productive resources

17BC5A4D04E8449EB9E6F65139212201.description: SSEC.C.17: explain why limited productive resources and unlimited wants result in scarcity, opportunity costs, and tradeoffs for individuals, businesses, and governments

BF6D7F660E73482F826B4530B65F2A50.description: SSEC.B.16.a: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

726525B3DCC74849BA12E374A5823B84.description: SSEC.B.15.g: draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

7F6B21D8B13C48BC993932E28E818CC8.description: SSEC.B.15.f: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

48A576BF0A7D465E90467A761CE598F8.description: SSEC.B.15.e: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

3457BEF391D54D5AA2A95FE94DC97905.description: SSEC.B.15.d: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

38AEE5B5B7DC4AA79EAF8029CB35D9B2.description: SSEC.B.15.c: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

EF3C28EC45CF43418D2940321045A13D.description: SSEC.B.15.b: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

3340668898784BB691D679EECAB68BB4.description: SSEC.B.15.a: evaluate authors' differing points of view on the same historical event or issue by assessing the authors' claims, reasoning, and evidence

BE9FA7257C034D3BBFC22B034DC1B47B.description: SSEC.B.15: check for consistency of information

FAD5F5034ED346C78EFE9DB334DDBDC7.description: SSEC.B.14.p: draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

1CEB8F56988345F383DEDBFA12F41180.description: SSEC.B.14.o: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

D7BFFC11AB294C81941314E13A5DF182.description: SSEC.B.14.n: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

1C941EE92917487A80D1D037675CFBE3.description: SSEC.B.14.m: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

D352BFC578684D79AF451C88983EC6C5.description: SSEC.B.14.l: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

E20EDC5BA0DE4CAF91F090DCE9BC1880.description: SSEC.B.14.k: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

E5E37DA4CCD9403E92743F6E06C9825F.description: SSEC.B.14.j: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by establishing and maintaining a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

2C681A2BFBCD46B79A91ADD40D55EF4F.description: SSEC.B.14.i: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by using words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims

CB8BA3A1839C40CA87CE9B111930639A.description: SSEC.B.14.h: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by introducing precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establishing the significance of the claim(s), distinguishing the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and creating an organization that logically sequences the claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence

270E6C6AE5284A39B93F9DE83298FCCD.description: SSEC.B.14.g: by the end of grade 12, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 11-12 text complexity band independently and proficiently

BB2D3F97376E4F7EA2319377CDE91C9C.description: SSEC.B.14.f: integrate information from diverse sources, both primary and secondary, into a coherent understanding of an idea or event, noting discrepancies among sources

F81346023E3246C3BD0D3E796B8DEB7C.description: SSEC.B.14.e: evaluate an author's premises, claims, and evidence by corroborating or challenging them with other information

A113CF7A21374B129D8351A9FCF1FFB5.description: SSEC.B.14.d: integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, as well as in words) in order to address a question or solve a problem

CC7C8F37A92A4CD0AE336A27D3E57454.description: SSEC.B.14.c: evaluate authors' differing points of view on the same historical event or issue by assessing the authors' claims, reasoning, and evidence

C887028C7555446A89514D423A6CE967.description: SSEC.B.14.b: analyze in detail how a complex primary source is structured, including how key sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text contribute to the whole

0301958A70534B82A26E78147388DBE2.description: SSEC.B.14.a: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including analyzing how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term over the course of a text

8F932CB7CD7E4C139D36BBF40EF048AC.description: SSEC.B.14: write arguments, informative text, and explanatory text that determine adequacy and/or relevancy of information

613F7DB32F504635B79B450C038CD7F2.description: SSEC.B.13.c: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

318F7E8B9E9B495F9817E03140E1C182.description: SSEC.B.13.b: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by establishing and maintaining a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

D9F8FBB2047A49CA9309ADFA05217039.description: SSEC.B.13.a: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by using words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims

E2BB25EE4FF040A794364AA8F882A276.description: SSEC.B.12.a: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

9C44B50246DA48BEB033E2E3EA7CAF1D.description: SSEC.B.11.m: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

0C5F52343E5A4F5E868A7536AA83AF2B.description: SSEC.B.11.l: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

2E7D670E5F204E8499A344F60BB469CD.description: SSEC.B.11.k: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

AC343D1E3C8E4FF0835DC778F9D84425.description: SSEC.B.11.j: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by providing a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation provided (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic)

C443F476DDD243B0BAA147214776759C.description: SSEC.B.11.i: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

EE03DCC62BB84C4D9D3494394C3AC993.description: SSEC.B.11.h: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

E6ED9C4968FC440AA8563C83E3198725.description: SSEC.B.11.g: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

66BA73CC27EC44B3A53A8FAC6759D7C6.description: SSEC.B.11.f: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by providing a concluding statement or section that follows from or supports the argument presented

BA8D1F05C62A4DC4AED6BA92B94BCDB6.description: SSEC.B.11.e: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by developing claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant data and evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both claim(s) and counterclaims in a discipline-appropriate form that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases

ECFC8A3093C246EA84E59F09D6F01B9E.description: SSEC.B.11.d: by the end of grade 12, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 11-12 text complexity band independently and proficiently

9D8A61D19F4A4F6C83BA5B4EF52941B9.description: SSEC.B.11.c: analyze in detail how a complex primary source is structured, including how key sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text contribute to the whole

F382B1E784F148CF897B3B9E4B499E00.description: SSEC.B.11.b: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including analyzing how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term over the course of a text

04981AEF95BD4466ADE6BEE5047C8440.description: SSEC.B.11.a: determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary that makes clear the relationships among the key details and ideas

88E7FAA9666F4159B53A8B61CB41C61D.description: SSEC.B.11: write arguments, informative text, and explanatory text that draw conclusions and make generalizations

0FC3C2516EFD4D978E8C02F660F42251.description: SSEC.B.10.a: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

E17F1EBFBFD149828CF9EE409F51BD7E.description: SSEC.B.9.t: draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

1E6B91610442424BB3C9D9AA773FA2BF.description: SSEC.B.9.s: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

CB6ED2112D1C4ED290406F731E58F585.description: SSEC.B.9.r: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

71626B64C8B3433495F09019C9CF16F9.description: SSEC.B.9.q: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

D4509766D2C0456B862EA1B81ACD4BE2.description: SSEC.B.9.p: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

FB1E9162B080459689F68DE3614FB4B4.description: SSEC.B.9.o: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

3591200BE6EF43E29A873802DE42281D.description: SSEC.B.9.n: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

8A250D2FF2B746199F429BC3534D0F99.description: SSEC.B.9.m: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

3DC103DBFF194F08AE47BDF6F587376D.description: SSEC.B.9.l: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by establishing and maintaining a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

D08FA53002C140C7B8E7F2F0AFB90545.description: SSEC.B.9.k: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by using words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims

86337BC8A0F8427F8257C42A418810A8.description: SSEC.B.9.j: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by introducing precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establishing the significance of the claim(s), distinguishing the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and creating an organization that logically sequences the claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence

C1878157D57A4E958325DC64CB89E763.description: SSEC.B.9.i: by the end of grade 12, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 11-12 text complexity band independently and proficiently

6E385C36E3894AC386C9094393DC4648.description: SSEC.B.9.h: integrate information from diverse sources, both primary and secondary, into a coherent understanding of an idea or event, noting discrepancies among sources

4EE0112C34634E92BF4637628E5E795D.description: SSEC.B.9.g: evaluate an author's premises, claims, and evidence by corroborating or challenging them with other information

001ECB017A064CA1A917AC758ACF7997.description: SSEC.B.9.f: integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, as well as in words) in order to address a question or solve a problem

A9BD9D4F9AA741849B889AA3787B51CC.description: SSEC.B.9.e: evaluate authors' differing points of view on the same historical event or issue by assessing the authors' claims, reasoning, and evidence

29082D93464944A9B17B6F412B99A759.description: SSEC.B.9.d: analyze in detail how a complex primary source is structured, including how key sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text contribute to the whole

BFC251325BEB48CD8D24FC4608EC71C9.description: SSEC.B.9.c: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including analyzing how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term over the course of a text

82C5102D883341FF8CFF6FC14276D4E3.description: SSEC.B.9.b: determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary that makes clear the relationships among the key details and ideas

A2A633A2677940E880030D560041BF6B.description: SSEC.B.9.a: cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources, connecting insights gained from specific details to an understanding of the text as a whole

289F2D179804476FB3081B9C92CD71BC.description: SSEC.B.9: identify social studies reference resources to use for a specific purpose

A1AE3BE52EBC42F7A6B6320803806473.description: SSEC.B.7.i: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

4ACA7B06EF854646B5CA41D540ED00A5.description: SSEC.B.7.h: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

822945393A7544AF849190294FA5A4DE.description: SSEC.B.7.g: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

5C3A6FD0C33A4934A5505A42824A429F.description: SSEC.A.4: compare maps with data sets (e.g., charts, tables, graphs) and/or readings to draw conclusions and make generalizations

6CC781F79AA6436C9E170D95D8457ED5.description: SSEC.A.1: compare and contrast the categories of natural, cultural, and political features found on maps as it relates to trade
